instruction: My tomato leaves have brown spots with yellow halos. What disease is this and how should I treat it?
output: This appears to be early blight caused by Alternaria solani. Remove affected leaves immediately, improve air circulation by spacing plants properly, avoid overhead watering to keep foliage dry, and apply copper-based fungicide every 7-10 days. Maintain proper spacing between plants and consider resistant varieties for future planting.

instruction: Emergency! Late blight spreading rapidly in greenhouse, 80% humidity, 18C. What immediate action?
output: Critical situation requiring immediate action: 1) Isolate affected area with plastic barriers, 2) Remove and destroy all infected plants in sealed bags, 3) Apply systemic fungicide (metalaxyl or dimethomorph) immediately to remaining plants, 4) Reduce humidity to below 60% using dehumidifiers and heating, 5) Increase air circulation to maximum. Monitor every 4 hours. This is Phytophthora infestans - can destroy entire crop in 3-5 days if unchecked.

instruction: Seeing V-shaped yellow lesions on leaf edges, plants wilting despite adequate water. Diagnosis?
output: This indicates bacterial wilt (Ralstonia solanacearum). Immediately remove infected plants with root ball, disinfect all tools with 10% bleach, avoid replanting in same soil for 3-4 years. Check irrigation water source for contamination. No chemical cure exists - prevention through resistant varieties and crop rotation essential. Monitor nearby plants for wilting symptoms.

instruction: Purple-brown lesions with concentric rings on stems near soil line. Plants falling over.
output: Collar rot caused by Alternaria or Phytophthora. Apply mefenoxam or azoxystrobin fungicide to stem base immediately. Improve drainage, reduce irrigation frequency, mulch to prevent soil splash. Support affected plants with stakes. Future prevention: raised beds, drip irrigation, resistant rootstocks. Monitor soil moisture - maintain at 60-70% field capacity only.

instruction: Sudden yellowing and necrosis spreading from leaf margins inward, affecting mature plants.
output: Likely Septoria leaf spot (Septoria lycopersici). Remove infected leaves below first fruit cluster, apply chlorothalonil or copper fungicide weekly. Ensure 1-1.5m plant spacing, stake plants for air circulation. Avoid working with wet plants. Rotate crops for 2-3 years. Water at soil level only. Disease favored by 20-25C with high humidity.

instruction: White cottony growth on stems with black sclerotia visible. High tunnel environment.
output: White mold (Sclerotinia sclerotiorum). Remove infected plants entirely, bag and destroy. Reduce humidity below 60%, increase spacing to 60cm minimum, improve ventilation significantly. Apply Contans WG (Coniothyrium minitans) biological control. Avoid nitrogen excess. Solarize soil in summer. Sclerotia survive 5+ years in soil.

instruction: Distorted young leaves with mosaic pattern, stunted growth, shoe-string appearance.
output: Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) or Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV). No cure - remove infected plants immediately. Disinfect hands/tools with 20% milk solution or trisodium phosphate between plants. Control aphids and thrips vectors. Use resistant varieties (Tm-2² gene). Avoid tobacco products near plants. Virus survives on surfaces for months.

instruction: Gray fuzzy mold on flowers and small fruits, spreading in cool humid conditions.
output: Gray mold (Botrytis cinerea). Remove infected flowers/fruits immediately, improve air circulation, reduce humidity to 65-70%. Apply iprodione or fenhexamid fungicides. Avoid overhead irrigation, prune for airflow, harvest fruits promptly. Temperature 18-23C with high humidity favors disease. Critical during flowering stage.

instruction: Cork-like lesions on fruit surface, rough and raised, mainly on exposed fruits.
output: Bacterial speck (Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato). Apply fixed copper plus mancozeb preventively. Occurs in cool (18-24C), moist conditions. Use pathogen-free seeds, avoid overhead irrigation, maintain 1m spacing. Harvest affected fruits early. Disease spreads via water splash. Resistant varieties available.

instruction: Leaves showing yellowing between veins, progressing to brown necrotic spots. pH 7.8.
output: Iron chlorosis due to high pH limiting iron availability. Apply chelated iron (Fe-EDDHA) at 2-5g per plant as soil drench. Lower pH to 6.0-6.8 using sulfur or sulfuric acid. Foliar spray with 0.5% ferrous sulfate for quick relief. Monitor weekly - iron critical for chlorophyll production.

instruction: Black sunken cankers on stems, white fungal growth in center, plants breaking at lesions.
output: Didymella stem canker (Didymella lycopersici). Prune infected stems 5cm below lesion with sterile tools. Apply thiophanate-methyl or azoxystrobin. Reduce humidity, avoid plant injuries, maintain calcium levels. Stakes should be disinfected. Disease enters through wounds. Crop rotation essential.

instruction: Roots showing brown discoloration, few white healthy roots visible, plants wilting midday.
output: Pythium root rot favored by overwatering. Reduce irrigation immediately, apply mefenoxam drench, improve drainage. Add perlite to growing medium, ensure containers have adequate drainage holes. Water only when top 2cm soil is dry. Beneficial microbes (Trichoderma) help suppress pathogen.

instruction: Small dark spots with white centers on older leaves, spreading upward rapidly.
output: Bacterial spot (Xanthomonas campestris). Apply copper hydroxide plus mancozeb every 5-7 days. Remove infected leaves, avoid overhead watering, increase plant spacing. Use resistant varieties, hot water seed treatment (50C for 25 min). Disease spreads rapidly in warm, humid conditions.

instruction: Fruit showing circular spots with alternating light and dark rings, sunken centers.
output: Anthracnose (Colletotrichum spp.). Apply azoxystrobin or chlorothalonil preventively. Harvest fruits before full ripeness, avoid fruit injury, improve drainage. Mulch to prevent soil splash. Store harvested fruits at 10-13C. Disease worse in warm (25-30C), humid conditions.

instruction: Young seedlings falling over at soil line, dark lesion at stem base.
output: Damping-off (Pythium/Rhizoctonia). Apply captan or mefenoxam to remaining seedlings. Reduce watering, increase air circulation, thin seedlings if overcrowded. Sterilize seed trays, use sterile growing medium. Maintain soil temperature 20-25C. Add beneficial microbes to suppress pathogens.

instruction: Seeing bronze-colored streaks on leaves and stems, ring spots on fruits.
output: Tomato spotted wilt virus (TSWV) transmitted by thrips. Control thrips immediately with spinosad, remove infected plants. Use reflective mulches, UV-absorbing greenhouse plastic. Monitor with blue sticky cards. Plant resistant varieties. No cure once infected. Early detection critical.

instruction: Water-soaked lesions on fruit, foul smell, rapid decay after rain.
output: Bacterial soft rot (Erwinia/Pectobacterium). Remove affected fruits immediately, improve air circulation, avoid overhead irrigation. Apply fixed copper preventively. Harvest before rain, handle fruits carefully to avoid wounds. Maintain storage at 10-13C with good ventilation.

instruction: Curled leaves with sticky honeydew, black sooty mold developing, whiteflies visible.
output: Whitefly infestation leading to sooty mold. Apply insecticidal soap or neem oil every 3 days. Install yellow sticky traps at canopy level (1 per 10m²). Release Encarsia formosa parasitic wasps. Remove heavily infested lower leaves. Maintain temperature below 27C. Monitor daily during warm periods.

instruction: Brown streaks inside fruit visible when cut, external appearance normal.
output: Internal browning/grey wall caused by multiple factors: tobacco mosaic virus, low light, high nitrogen, or potassium deficiency. Test for TMV first. Increase potassium to 300ppm, reduce nitrogen, improve light penetration. Maintain day temperature 24-26C. Some varieties more susceptible.

instruction: Leaves cupping downward, becoming thick and leathery, purple veins visible.
output: Phosphorus deficiency aggravated by cold soil (<15C). Apply monopotassium phosphate foliar spray at 0.5% weekly. Warm soil with black plastic mulch, maintain root zone >18C. Add bone meal or rock phosphate for long-term correction. Purple color from anthocyanin accumulation.

instruction: Target-like spots on fruit with bird's eye appearance, affecting marketability.
output: Bacterial canker (Clavibacter michiganensis). No cure - remove infected plants and 2 adjacent plants. Disinfect all equipment with 10% bleach. Use certified disease-free seeds, practice 3-year rotation. Copper sprays provide limited protection. Highly contagious through mechanical transmission.

instruction: Sudden wilting of entire plant sections, vascular browning visible in stem cross-section.
output: Fusarium wilt (Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici). Remove entire plant including roots, solarize soil for 6-8 weeks. No chemical cure available. Use resistant varieties (VF designation), grafted plants on resistant rootstock. Pathogen persists in soil 10+ years. Avoid moving soil between beds.

instruction: Powdery white coating on upper leaf surfaces, yellowing underneath.
output: Powdery mildew (Leveillula taurica or Oidium lycopersici). Apply sulfur dust or potassium bicarbonate weekly. Maintain humidity 50-70%, increase air circulation. Remove infected leaves carefully (spores spread easily). Silicon supplements increase resistance. Unlike most fungi, thrives in dry conditions.

instruction: Pitted, corky areas on fruit surface, worse on sun-exposed side.
output: Tomato pox caused by feeding injury from stink bugs or bacterial infection. For insects, apply pyrethrin; for bacteria, copper sprays. Provide shade during extreme heat, maintain consistent calcium levels. Harvest affected fruits early. More common in field production than protected culture.

instruction: Fine webbing on leaf undersides, stippling damage, leaves bronzing.
output: Two-spotted spider mite infestation. Spray abamectin or bifenazate, repeat after 5 days to kill newly hatched mites. Increase humidity above 60%, release predatory mites (Phytoseiulus persimilis). Avoid broad-spectrum pesticides killing beneficials. Population explodes in hot, dry conditions.

instruction: Seeing circular lesions with dark margins on lower leaves, 28°C, 75% humidity. Started 3 days ago spreading upward.
output: This indicates Alternaria leaf spot (early blight) in early stages. Immediately remove affected lower leaves and dispose in sealed bags. Apply chlorothalonil or copper-based fungicide every 7 days, rotating with mancozeb to prevent resistance. Improve air circulation by pruning and spacing plants. Mulch soil to prevent splash. Long-term: use resistant varieties, maintain 60-70% humidity, avoid overhead watering.

instruction: Emergency: 60% of greenhouse showing water-soaked spots turning black, spreading rapidly in 24 hours. 22°C, 85% humidity.
output: Critical late blight outbreak (Phytophthora infestans). Immediately quarantine affected area with plastic barriers. Remove and burn all infected plants within 2m radius. Apply systemic fungicide (metalaxyl-M + mancozeb) to remaining plants immediately, repeat in 5 days. Reduce humidity below 75% urgently using heaters and maximum ventilation. Monitor every 6 hours. This can destroy entire crop in 72 hours if unchecked.

instruction: Yellow V-shaped lesions starting from leaf tips, black veins visible. Plants 8 weeks old, drip irrigation system.
output: Bacterial canker (Clavibacter michiganensis) infection. No cure available - remove infected plants plus 2 adjacent plants immediately. Disinfect all tools with 70% alcohol between each plant. Stop overhead irrigation permanently. Apply copper hydroxide preventively to remaining plants every 5 days. Test irrigation water for contamination. Future: use certified disease-free seeds, implement strict sanitation protocols.

instruction: White fungal growth under leaves, yellow patches on top, spreading in high tunnel. Morning dew present daily.
output: Leaf mold (Fulvia fulva) thriving in high humidity. Reduce humidity below 85% immediately through ventilation and heating. Remove affected leaves in dry conditions to prevent spore spread. Apply chlorothalonil alternating with mancozeb every 7 days. Install horizontal airflow fans. Prune lower leaves for circulation. Resistant varieties essential for high tunnels. Never work with wet plants.

instruction: Sudden wilting of entire plant despite moist soil, brown streaks in stem when cut. No external symptoms.
output: Fusarium wilt (Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici) - vascular disease. Remove entire plant with root ball immediately, do not compost. No chemical cure exists. Solarize soil for 6-8 weeks or replace entirely. Use resistant varieties (VF designation). Graft susceptible varieties onto resistant rootstock. Pathogen survives 10+ years in soil. Implement 4-year crop rotation.

instruction: Ring-shaped patterns on fruits, distorted new growth, plants stunted. Aphids present last week.
output: Tomato spotted wilt virus (TSWV) transmitted by thrips. No cure - remove infected plants immediately to prevent spread. Control thrips aggressively with spinosad or abamectin. Install reflective mulch to repel thrips. Use UV-absorbing greenhouse film. Monitor with blue sticky traps (1 per 20m²). Plant resistant varieties. Destroy all solanaceous weeds nearby.

instruction: Gray-brown spots with yellow halos, concentric rings visible with lens. Heavy rain last 3 days.
output: Target spot (Corynespora cassiicola) favored by wet conditions. Apply azoxystrobin immediately, rotate with chlorothalonil and mancozeb. Remove affected leaves when dry. Improve drainage around plants. Space plants for airflow. Stake plants off ground. This disease develops resistance quickly - strict fungicide rotation essential. Can cause 50% yield loss if unchecked.

instruction: Bleached white spots on fruit exposed to sun, tissue papery. Temperature reached 38°C yesterday.
output: Sunscald damage from extreme temperature and UV exposure. Not a disease but creates entry points for pathogens. Provide 30-40% shade cloth during extreme heat. Never remove leaves above fruit clusters. Apply kaolin clay spray for reflection. Harvest affected fruits immediately before secondary rot. Maintain adequate foliage through balanced nutrition. Choose varieties with dense canopy.

instruction: Roots with round swellings, plants stunted and yellowing. Sandy soil, second year same location.
output: Root-knot nematodes (Meloidogyne spp.) severe infestation. No quick cure. Apply organic matter with chitinase (crab/shrimp meal) to suppress population. Plant marigolds (Tagetes patula) as biofumigant. Solarize soil in summer for 6 weeks. Use resistant varieties or grafted plants. Rotate with brassicas. Chemical nematicides restricted. Long-term soil health approach required.

instruction: Brown corky streaks on stems, leaves curling downward. Used compost from lawn clippings.
output: Herbicide injury from persistent herbicides (aminopyralid/clopyralid) in compost. No remedy - damage is permanent. Remove contaminated soil/compost completely. Test new compost with bioassay before use. Symptoms persist entire season. Document source for legal action. Use only certified organic compost or known clean sources. These herbicides persist 3+ years.

instruction: Purple-red leaves, interveinal chlorosis, poor fruit set. pH meter shows 7.8.
output: Phosphorus lockout due to high pH. Phosphorus unavailable above pH 7.5. Apply phosphoric acid to lower pH to 6.0-6.5. Foliar feed with monopotassium phosphate (0.5%) for quick relief. Add sulfur to soil for long-term pH reduction. Monitor pH weekly. High pH also limits iron, manganese, zinc availability. Consider switching to acidic fertilizers.

instruction: Mottled yellowing between veins, leaves feel rough, transmitted plant-to-plant by workers.
output: Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) spreading through mechanical transmission. Disinfect hands/tools with 20% skim milk or 10% trisodium phosphate between EVERY plant. Remove infected plants. Prohibit tobacco use near plants. Use resistant varieties (Tm-2² gene). Virus survives on surfaces for years. Train workers on sanitation. No cure once infected.

instruction: Black sunken areas at blossom end of green fruits. Irregular watering schedule admitted.
output: Blossom end rot from calcium deficiency and water stress. Not a disease but physiological disorder. Maintain consistent soil moisture (never wet-dry cycles). Apply calcium chloride foliar spray (0.5%) weekly. Ensure calcium in fertilizer program (150-200ppm). Mulch to maintain moisture. Pick affected fruits. Avoid excess nitrogen/potassium competing with calcium uptake.

instruction: Yellowing starting from bottom, moving up systematically. Nitrogen levels test normal.
output: If nitrogen adequate, suspect Verticillium wilt (Verticillium dahliae). Check for brown vascular streaks in stem. Cool soil temperatures favor disease. No cure - remove infected plants. Solarize soil or fumigate. Use resistant varieties (V designation). Rotate with non-hosts (grasses, corn) for 4 years. Disease worse in cool springs. Maintain soil temperature above 24°C.

instruction: Sticky honeydew on leaves, black sooty mold developing. Tiny white insects flying when disturbed.
output: Whitefly infestation causing secondary sooty mold. Apply insecticidal soap or neem oil every 3 days for 2 weeks. Install yellow sticky traps at canopy level (1 per 10m²). Release Encarsia formosa parasitic wasps for biological control. Remove heavily infested lower leaves. Maintain temperatures below 27°C. Reflective mulch repels adults. Monitor undersides of leaves.

instruction: Puckered leaves with light/dark mosaic pattern, fruits small with internal browning.
output: Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) advanced symptoms. Remove infected plants immediately. Virus spreads easily through sap. Disinfect everything - tools, stakes, hands. No cure available. Use resistant varieties. Test seeds for virus. Avoid touching plants unnecessarily. Can reduce yields 20-50%. Practice strict hygiene protocols. Consider destroying entire crop if widespread.

instruction: Water-soaked spots on stems near soil, white mold with black structures. High density planting.
output: Sclerotinia stem rot (white mold). Remove infected plants entirely in bags. Reduce humidity below 70%, increase plant spacing to 50cm minimum. Apply Contans WG (biological control) to soil. Avoid excess nitrogen. Deep plow to bury sclerotia. Disease favored by cool, wet conditions. Sclerotia survive 5+ years. Improve air circulation urgently.

instruction: Bronze-colored necrotic streaks on stems and leaves, circular spots on fruits. Thrips visible.
output: Tomato spotted wilt virus vectored by thrips. Control thrips immediately with spinosad, rotate with abamectin. Remove all infected plants. Use reflective mulch, UV-absorbing plastic. Mass trap with blue sticky cards. Release minute pirate bugs (Orius) for biocontrol. Plant resistant varieties. Early detection critical - monitor new growth weekly.

instruction: Chlorotic spots turning tan with dark margins, shot-hole appearance. Overhead irrigation used.
output: Bacterial speck (Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato). Apply copper + mancozeb immediately, repeat every 5 days during wet weather. Stop overhead irrigation permanently. Remove affected leaves when dry. Maintain temperatures above 24°C (disease favors cool conditions). Use pathogen-free seeds. Practice 3-year rotation. Spreads rapidly in rain.

instruction: Fruit rot starting at stem, spreading downward, gray sporulation in humid conditions.
output: Gray mold (Botrytis cinerea) on fruits. Remove infected fruits immediately in sealed bags. Reduce humidity to 60-70%, increase air circulation. Apply iprodione or fenhexamid fungicide. Avoid injuries during harvest. Pick fruits in dry conditions. Store at 10-13°C with good ventilation. Sanitize storage areas. Common in dense plantings.

instruction: Interveinal yellowing on new growth only, veins remain green. pH 6.2, EC normal.
output: Iron deficiency typical symptoms. Apply chelated iron (Fe-EDDHA) at 2-5g per plant as soil drench. Foliar spray with 0.5% ferrous sulfate for quick response. Check for root damage limiting uptake. Excess phosphorus can limit iron availability. Maintain soil temperature above 18°C for uptake. Symptoms reverse in 7-10 days with treatment.

instruction: Dark brown lesions girdling stem at soil line, plants falling over. Recent transplants.
output: Collar rot (Phytophthora or Rhizoctonia) at critical stage. Apply mefenoxam or azoxystrobin as soil drench immediately. Improve drainage, reduce irrigation frequency. Stake affected plants for support. Avoid deep planting, maintain dry stem base. Future: use raised beds, drip irrigation, resistant rootstocks. Monitor soil moisture carefully.

instruction: Leaves cupping upward, veins purple, growth stunted. Night temperature 10°C for a week.
output: Phosphorus deficiency induced by cold soil. Phosphorus unavailable below 15°C soil temperature. Apply foliar monopotassium phosphate (0.5%) immediately. Warm soil with black plastic mulch or row covers. Maintain minimum 18°C root zone. Add bone meal for slow release. Purple color from anthocyanin accumulation. Recovery takes 2 weeks after warming.

instruction: Small dark spots with white centers on older leaves, spreading rapidly after rain.
output: Septoria leaf spot (Septoria lycopersici). Remove infected leaves below first fruit cluster immediately. Apply chlorothalonil or copper fungicide every 7 days, more frequently in wet weather. Mulch to prevent splash. Stake plants, prune for airflow. Avoid working with wet plants. Disease favors 20-25°C with moisture. Can defoliate plants if unchecked.

instruction: Flower drop without fruit set, temperature 34°C daytime, 26°C night. Flowers appear normal.
output: Heat stress preventing pollination. Pollen sterile above 32°C day or 24°C night. Provide 30% shade cloth immediately. Mist flowers early morning. Apply calcium chloride + boron foliar spray. Consider growth regulators (4-CPA) to force fruit set. Maintain humidity 60-70% during flowering. Select heat-tolerant varieties for summer production.

instruction: Circular water-soaked spots on leaves after hail damage, now turning black with yellow halos.
output: Bacterial spot (Xanthomonas) entering through hail wounds. Apply copper + mancozeb immediately as protective treatment. Remove severely damaged tissue. Avoid working with plants for 48 hours. Disease spreads rapidly in injured tissue. Continue protective sprays every 5 days until wounds heal. Document for insurance. Consider protective netting.

instruction: Wilting progressively from top down, lower leaves remain turgid. Grafted plants, 3 months old.
output: Possible graft incompatibility or vascular blockage at union. Check graft union for abnormal swelling or constriction. May be Ralstonia solanacearum if bacterial ooze present. Remove affected plants, check adjacent ones. For incompatibility, no solution exists. Verify rootstock/scion compatibility. Document variety combination. May need to replant with compatible combinations.

instruction: Purple spots on leaves, fuzzy gray growth underneath. Cool greenhouse, poor ventilation.
output: Blue mold (Peronospora) in suboptimal conditions. Increase temperature above 20°C, reduce humidity below 75%. Apply phosphorous acid or mefenoxam. Improve ventilation immediately. Remove infected leaves carefully (spores spread easily). This disease rare in tomatoes but severe in cool, humid conditions. Space plants adequately.

instruction: Fruit showing ghost spot - white rings with dark centers. No other symptoms on plant.
output: Ghost spot from Botrytis spore germination without infection. Cosmetic issue mainly. Indicates high humidity during fruit development. Reduce humidity, increase air circulation. Fruits safe to eat but unmarketable. Apply iprodione preventively. Harvest affected fruits early. Problem worse in dense plantings. Improve ventilation around fruit clusters.

instruction: Seedlings showing wire stem - stem constricted and dark at soil line but not damping off.
output: Rhizoctonia wire stem disease. Different from damping-off as plants survive but remain stunted. Apply fludioxonil or azoxystrobin as drench. Reduce soil moisture, increase temperature to 24°C. Improve air circulation at soil level. Transplant deeper to encourage adventitious roots. Sterilize containers and media for next crop.

instruction: Leaves show oak-leaf pattern, narrow and distorted. Seeds saved from hybrid varieties.
output: Genetic abnormality from saved hybrid seeds, not disease. F2 generation segregating with various deformities. Cannot be corrected. Replace with commercial F1 hybrid seeds or open-pollinated varieties suitable for seed saving. Document for education. May show varying symptoms. Never save seeds from hybrid varieties for commercial production.

instruction: Brown necrotic spots on all plant parts including fruit, after copper spray in hot weather.
output: Copper phytotoxicity from application during stress conditions. No reversal possible for damaged tissue. Flush foliage with clean water. Apply calcium and amino acids for recovery. Never spray copper above 30°C or on stressed plants. New growth will be normal. Reduce copper concentration in hot weather. Add lime to copper for safety.

instruction: Multiple diseases appearing simultaneously after flooding event. Where to start?
output: Post-flood disease complex requires systematic approach. First, improve drainage immediately. Apply broad-spectrum fungicide (chlorothalonil + metalaxyl) for multiple pathogens. Remove all diseased material. Treat soil with beneficial microbes to compete with pathogens. Monitor for bacterial diseases (favored by flooding). May need to abandon severely affected areas.

instruction: Unusual purple-black lesions on fruit, internal browning, bitter taste. Near industrial area.
output: Possible air pollution damage (sulfur dioxide or ozone). Test for environmental contaminants. Install air filtration if in greenhouse. No treatment for damaged fruit. Document patterns relative to wind direction. Consider legal action if source identified. Use tolerant varieties. May need to relocate production. Monitor air quality regularly.

instruction: Cankers on main stem oozing amber fluid, rapid decline. Pruning wounds present.
output: Bacterial stem canker through pruning wounds. Remove infected plants entirely. Disinfect all tools between cuts with 70% alcohol or 10% bleach. Apply copper to wounds immediately after pruning. Avoid pruning in humid conditions. Train workers on sanitation. Use clean, sharp tools. This spreads rapidly through mechanical transmission.

instruction: Yellowing in distinct patches across greenhouse, spreading pattern suggests root issue.
output: Suspect root disease spread through irrigation system. Test drainage water for Pythium, Phytophthora. Check irrigation line contamination. Apply mefenoxam through irrigation system. Improve drainage in affected zones. Disinfect irrigation system with hydrogen peroxide. May indicate water source contamination. Map spread pattern for source identification.

instruction: Fruit developing normally then suddenly rotting from inside out. No external symptoms.
output: Internal fruit rot possibly from Alternaria or bacterial infection during flowering. Infection occurred weeks ago during bloom. Maintain dry conditions during flowering. Avoid overhead irrigation during bloom. Apply preventive fungicides at flowering. Remove affected fruits immediately. Can spread during harvest handling. Sort carefully at harvest.

instruction: Leaves showing intervienal chlorosis in chevron pattern, worse on one side of greenhouse.
output: Magnesium deficiency pattern suggests pH or irrigation issue on affected side. Test soil/water pH in problem area. Apply Epsom salt (magnesium sulfate) at 2g/L foliar spray. Check for calcium excess causing antagonism. Investigate irrigation uniformity. Pattern suggests systematic cause not disease. Correct underlying cause.

instruction: New variety showing disease susceptibility not seen in previous varieties. Management strategy?
output: Variety lacks resistance genes of previous cultivars. Implement intensive preventive program: increase scouting frequency, preventive fungicide applications, optimize environment to discourage disease. Consider grafting onto resistant rootstock. Document specific susceptibilities. May need to switch varieties if management costs excessive. Contact seed supplier about resistance claims.

instruction: Biocontrol agents applied but disease still progressing. What went wrong?
output: Biocontrol failure from: incorrect timing (apply preventively not curatively), incompatible pesticides used, environmental conditions unsuitable, poor product quality, or overwhelming disease pressure. Check: storage conditions, expiration date, application timing, temperature/humidity requirements. Biocontrols prevent, not cure. May need chemical intervention then restart biocontrol program.

instruction: Dark streaks in fruit flesh, external appearance normal. Safe to sell?
output: Internal browning/gray wall from multiple causes: virus infection, nutritional imbalance, environmental stress. Test for viruses. Not harmful but affects quality. Cannot sell as Grade A. Consider processing market. Check potassium levels, temperature fluctuations during fruit development. Some varieties prone. Document occurrence rate for variety evaluation.

instruction: Disease pressure increasing despite following spray schedule. Resistance developing?
output: Likely fungicide resistance development. Immediately rotate to different mode of action (check FRAC codes). Never use same fungicide group consecutively. Implement resistance management: tank mixing, alternation, use multisite fungicides. Send samples for resistance testing. May need to abandon certain fungicides. Document ineffective treatments. Review and revise spray program.

instruction: Leaf spots appeared 3 days after transplanting nursery seedlings. Source contamination?
output: High probability of infected transplants from nursery. Quarantine new plants, inspect all thoroughly. Contact supplier immediately, document with photos. Apply broad-spectrum fungicide to all transplants. Consider compensation claim. Implement receiving inspection protocol. Future: source from certified disease-free nurseries only. May need to destroy infected batch.

instruction: Workers report allergic reactions when handling diseased plants. Safety protocol?
output: Fungal spores causing respiratory/skin reactions. Provide N95 masks, gloves, long sleeves for disease management work. Remove workers with severe reactions. Ensure ventilation when removing diseased material. Some fungi (Botrytis, Alternaria) are strong allergens. Document reactions for workers' compensation. Consider mechanizing diseased plant removal.

instruction: Organic disease control failing in humid climate. Alternative strategies?
output: Humid conditions challenge organic systems. Focus on: environmental control (dehumidification critical), resistant varieties (essential), physical barriers (rain shelters, high tunnels), aggressive pruning for airflow, wider spacing, potassium bicarbonate for powdery mildew, copper careful use. Accept some yield loss. Consider protected culture investment. Biological controls need optimal conditions.

instruction: Disease appearing in same spot every year despite crop rotation. Soil-borne issue?
output: Persistent soil pathogen or environmental factor. Deep soil sampling for pathogen identification. Consider soil replacement or deep solarization. Check drainage patterns, low spots accumulate pathogens. May be nematodes or long-lived pathogens (Fusarium, Verticillium). Fumigate if allowed. Long-term: improve soil biology, drainage. Document pattern for permanent solution.

instruction: Greenhouse disinfection between crops - overkill or necessary?
output: Essential for disease management. Protocol: remove all plant debris, pressure wash everything, apply disinfectant (quaternary ammonium or hydrogen peroxide), clean irrigation systems, replace or sterilize stakes/clips, steam or replace growing media. Allow drying time. Prevents carry-over of pathogens. Cost-effective compared to disease losses. Document for certification programs.

instruction: Disease diagnostic service results inconclusive. Next steps?
output: Get second opinion from another lab. Provide fresh samples, include healthy tissue for comparison. Detail environmental conditions, management history. Consider multiple issues present. Try different diagnostic methods (culture, PCR, ELISA). University extension services often more thorough than commercial labs. May need to treat symptomatically while investigating.

instruction: Powdery mildew spreading despite sulfur applications. Why isn't it working?
output: Sulfur fails when: temperature too low (<18°C) or too high (>30°C), applied after infection established, resistance developed, or wrong species (Leveillula needs systemic fungicide). Switch to potassium bicarbonate or systemic fungicides. Check pH of spray solution. Some varieties sulfur-sensitive. Ensure thorough coverage including undersides.

instruction: Disease spread pattern suggests worker transmission. How to prove and prevent?
output: Map disease occurrence relative to work patterns. If following row sequence, likely mechanical transmission. Implement: mandatory hand sanitization stations, tool disinfection between plants, work from healthy to diseased areas, dedicated tools for diseased sections, training on disease spread. Change work flow patterns. Document improvement to verify cause.

instruction: Fruit rot increasing during storage despite proper temperature. Hidden factors?
output: Check: ethylene levels (accelerates senescence), humidity (too high promotes rot, too low causes shriveling), air circulation, initial disease load at harvest, handling damage creating entry points. Sort more carefully at harvest. Consider chlorine wash. Ensure rapid cooling. Storage sanitation critical. Some infections latent until ripening.

instruction: Neighboring farm has severe disease outbreak. Preventive measures?
output: Implement biosecurity immediately: restrict visitor access, disinfect vehicles, no shared equipment, monitor wind direction, install insect screening if vector-borne, preventive fungicide applications on borders, increase scouting frequency. Communicate with neighbor about management. Document measures taken. Some diseases spread miles by wind. Consider insurance.

instruction: Disease symptoms inconsistent with textbook descriptions. Diagnosis approach?
output: Real-world symptoms often vary from textbooks. Consider: mixed infections, environmental stress modifying symptoms, variety-specific reactions, nutritional factors masking disease. Document thoroughly with photos. Isolate and culture pathogens. Send to diagnostic lab. Consider consulting specialist. May be new strain or unusual conditions. Keep affected plants isolated.

instruction: Resistance breeding program for local disease pressure. Feasibility?
output: Small-scale breeding feasible for specific issues. Identify resistant plants in diseased fields, save seeds, grow out, select survivors. Takes 5-7 generations for stability. Document disease pressure, selection criteria. Partner with university if possible. Focus on one disease initially. Consider participatory breeding with other growers. Long-term investment but valuable.

instruction: Disease management costs exceeding profit margins. Economic decisions?
output: Analyze cost-benefit: calculate treatment costs vs expected losses, consider resistant varieties despite lower yields, evaluate protected culture investment, explore premium markets for disease-free produce. May need to switch crops temporarily. Document all costs for business decisions. Consider crop insurance. Sometimes accepting some loss more economical than treatment.

instruction: Climate change increasing disease pressure. Adaptation strategies?
output: Adapt to new disease patterns: monitor emerging diseases from warmer regions, trial resistant varieties from different zones, invest in environmental controls, adjust planting dates, implement robust scouting program. Join disease alert networks. Increase management flexibility. Consider protected culture. Build resilience through diversity. Document changes for long-term planning.

instruction: Mysterious die-off in specific greenhouse zone, all other areas healthy. Investigation?
output: Zone-specific issue suggests localized cause. Check: irrigation malfunction (too much/little water), heating/cooling problems, chemical contamination (cleaning products, pesticide drift), carbon monoxide from heaters, electrical issues affecting root zone, structural issues (cold spots, leaks). Test soil, water, air in affected zone. Compare all environmental data with healthy zones.

instruction: Disease-free certification required for export. Preparation process?
output: Start 6 months before: implement strict sanitation protocols, document all disease management, schedule official inspections, maintain detailed records, segregate export crop, increase monitoring frequency. Zero tolerance for certain diseases. May need virus testing, nematode assays. Work with certifying agency early. Costs significant but opens premium markets.

instruction: Antiviral products claiming to cure virus infections. Worth trying?
output: No true antiviral cure exists for plant viruses. Products may boost plant immunity temporarily but virus remains. Focus on prevention: resistant varieties, vector control, sanitation. Remove infected plants. Some products induce systemic resistance providing slight suppression. Cost rarely justified. Research claims carefully. University trials show minimal efficacy.

instruction: Disease forecasting app recommending daily sprays. Seems excessive?
output: Generic models often over-prescribe. Calibrate to local conditions: adjust thresholds based on variety resistance, your management style, historical pressure. Use as guide not prescription. Combine with scouting observations. Track accuracy over season. Some apps designed for risk-averse approach. Economic thresholds important. Document to refine predictions.

instruction: Switching to biopesticides but disease control declining. Transition strategy?
output: Biopesticides require different approach: apply preventively not curatively, need optimal conditions (temperature, humidity), more frequent applications, may need higher rates initially. Don't abandon chemicals completely during transition. Use integrated approach. Takes time to establish beneficial populations. Expect 1-2 season adjustment period. Monitor closely, document results.

instruction: Root disease suspected but roots look healthy. Other diagnostic approaches?
output: Vascular pathogens may not show root symptoms. Cut stem lengthwise, check for browning. Some pathogens only in root tips or fine roots. Try water culture test - place stem in water, look for bacterial streaming. PCR testing most definitive. Check drainage patterns. Some symptoms delayed. Consider replant test in sterilized vs field soil.

instruction: Insurance requiring documentation of disease losses. What records needed?
output: Document: first appearance date/location, spread pattern with dates, photos at multiple stages, diagnostic lab reports, weather data correlation, all treatment applications with receipts, yield loss calculations. Map affected areas. Keep samples if possible. Third-party verification helpful. Maintain season-long records. Include labor costs for management. Professional assessment may be required.

instruction: Disease wiping out heirloom variety collection. Preservation strategies?
output: Emergency preservation: collect seeds from healthiest plants immediately, tissue culture from clean shoot tips, send samples to germplasm repository. Future: maintain backup plantings in isolated location, cryo-preservation of seeds, share with other growers for redundancy. Document variety characteristics. Some varieties irreplaceable. Consider controlled environment for maintenance. Network with seed savers.

instruction: Consultant recommending expensive disease management program. Second opinion needed?
output: Get multiple opinions: university extension (usually free), other consultants, experienced growers. Evaluate: necessity vs insurance approach, expected ROI, alternative strategies. Request scientific basis for recommendations. Check consultant's credentials, potential conflicts of interest. Start with partial implementation. Document baseline for comparison. Some programs over-engineered for small operations.

instruction: New disease spreading globally via trade. Quarantine preparation?
output: Proactive biosecurity: stay informed through alerts, restrict plant material imports, quarantine all new plants 30 days, train staff on symptoms, establish monitoring protocol, identify and remove alternative hosts, prepare response plan. Network with regional growers for early warning. May affect variety choices, sourcing. Consider regulatory implications. Prevention far cheaper than eradication.

instruction: Heritage greenhouse has recurring disease issues. Structural factors?
output: Old structures harbor pathogens: wooden frames rot and harbor disease, poor ventilation design, inadequate drainage, difficult to clean surfaces, outdated heating creating humidity problems. Consider: renovation vs replacement cost analysis, thorough disinfection and sealing, ventilation upgrades, drainage improvements. Document issues for renovation planning. May need professional assessment.

instruction: Soil test shows disease suppressive potential low. How to improve?
output: Build suppressive capacity: add diverse organic matter (various composts), inoculate with beneficial organisms, maintain pH 6.5-7.0, ensure good drainage, minimize soil disturbance, rotate with biofumigant crops. Takes 2-3 years minimum. Monitor soil biology tests. Avoid practices that harm beneficials. Long-term investment in soil health. Document improvements.

instruction: Young plants from tissue culture showing unexpected disease susceptibility. Why?
output: Tissue culture plants lack natural microbiome providing protection. Gradually acclimate: inoculate with beneficial microbes, harden off properly, avoid stress during establishment. Initial susceptibility normal. Build immunity through controlled exposure. Some somaclonal variation affects disease resistance. Document performance vs traditional propagation. May need adjusted management early on.

instruction: Disease modeling software subscription expensive. Worth the investment?
output: Calculate ROI: compare subscription cost to potential fungicide savings and yield loss prevention. Most valuable for large operations or high disease pressure areas. Consider: shared subscription with neighbors, university programs offering free access, simpler free models initially. Track accuracy first season. Some regions have public warning systems. Start with trial period if available.

instruction: Temperature 32C, humidity 90%, CO2 800ppm. Plants showing stress. What's the priority?
output: Critical heat and humidity stress. Priority: 1) Immediate cooling - activate all fans, wet walls, shade screens. 2) Reduce humidity - increase ventilation despite CO2 loss. 3) Emergency misting every 20 minutes. Target 25C and 70% humidity within 2 hours. Monitor for disease outbreak in next 48 hours due to stress conditions.

instruction: Night temperature 8C, day 22C. Fruit set very poor. How to optimize?
output: Night temperature too low for fruit set (minimum 13C needed). Install heating to maintain 15-17C nights. The 14C day/night differential is excessive - aim for 6-8C difference. Poor fruit set below 13C due to pollen sterility. Consider growth regulators (4-CPA) for fruit set in cold conditions. Monitor flower drop rates.

instruction: Light levels at 150 PPFD during flowering stage. Is supplementation needed?
output: Critically insufficient light for flowering (need 400-600 PPFD minimum). Install LED supplemental lighting immediately providing additional 300-450 PPFD. Use red:blue ratio 5:1 with far-red supplementation. Run 14-16 hour photoperiod. Poor light causes flower abortion, weak stems, reduced fruit set. Monitor daily light integral (DLI) - target 20-30 mol/m²/day.

instruction: VPD reading 0.3 kPa in seedling area. How should I adjust?
output: VPD too low for seedlings (optimal 0.6-0.8 kPa). Either increase temperature by 2-3C or reduce humidity by 10-15%. Low VPD reduces transpiration, limiting nutrient uptake and increasing disease risk. Adjust gradually over 2-3 hours. Install horizontal air flow fans. Monitor hourly until stable at 0.7 kPa.

instruction: CO2 drops to 150ppm during peak photosynthesis. Enrichment strategy?
output: Severe CO2 depletion limiting photosynthesis by 50%. Install CO2 enrichment to maintain 1000-1200ppm during light hours. Use burners for heating season, liquid CO2 in summer. Calculate: 0.5-1.0 kg CO2 per 100m² per hour. Include sensors at canopy level, controller with photosensor integration. ROI: 20-30% yield increase.

instruction: Greenhouse plastic transmitting only 60% light. Cleaning or replacement?
output: Below acceptable threshold (need >70% transmission). First try cleaning with soft brush and mild detergent solution. If still <70% after cleaning, replacement necessary. Double-layer inflated polyethylene provides better insulation. Consider diffused plastic for better light distribution. Anti-drip coating reduces disease. Replace every 3-4 years typically.

instruction: Power outage expected for 6 hours, outside temperature -5C. Emergency protocol?
output: Emergency cold protection protocol: 1) Cover plants with row covers/blankets before power loss, 2) Fill black containers with hot water for thermal mass, 3) Group plants together, 4) Seal all vents/cracks, 5) Use propane heaters with CO monitor if available. Priority: protect growing points and young fruits. Expect some damage below 5C.

instruction: How to calculate and maintain optimal DLI for fruiting tomatoes?
output: Target DLI 22-30 mol/m²/day for fruiting stage. Calculate: PPFD × hours × 0.0036. Example: 600 PPFD × 12 hours × 0.0036 = 25.9 mol/m²/day. Measure with quantum sensor at canopy level. Supplement if natural light provides <20 DLI. Adjust based on variety - cherry tomatoes tolerate higher DLI (30-35).

instruction: Setting up climate zones for propagation, vegetative, and fruiting areas?
output: Zone 1 (Propagation): 24-26C, 80-85% RH, 200 PPFD, 16hr photoperiod. Zone 2 (Vegetative): 22-24C, 70-75% RH, 400 PPFD, 14hr. Zone 3 (Fruiting): 20-22C day/16-18C night, 65-70% RH, 600+ PPFD, 12hr. Use curtains between zones, separate climate controls. Position sensors at plant level in each zone.

instruction: Condensation dripping on plants every morning causing disease. Solutions?
output: Implement pre-dawn dehumidification: Start heating + minimum ventilation 1 hour before sunrise. Maintain pipe temperature 2C above dew point. Install anti-drip greenhouse film or condensation gutters. Use horizontal airflow fans continuously. Target morning RH <80%. Apply fungicide preventively if problem persists.

instruction: Integrating weather forecast for predictive climate control?
output: Use weather API for 48-hour forecast integration. Pre-cool before heat waves, pre-heat before cold snaps. Adjust irrigation based on predicted solar radiation. Modify CO2 enrichment for cloudy periods. Example: if storm approaching, reduce humidity 12 hours early to prevent disease. 10-15% energy savings possible.

instruction: Summer temperatures reaching 42C outside. Cooling strategy for greenhouse?
output: Multi-layer cooling approach: 1) External shade cloth (50-60% shade), 2) Roof whitewash with removable shading compound, 3) Pad-and-fan evaporative cooling targeting 8-10C reduction, 4) High-pressure fog system at 70 bar, 5) Maximum ventilation with all vents open. Run irrigation at night. Consider temporary crop suspension above 40C.

instruction: Humidity spikes to 95% at night. Disease risk management?
output: Critical disease risk - implement immediate dehumidification. Heat minimum 2C while ventilating 5% to expel moisture. Run HAF fans continuously at maximum. Apply preventive fungicide before sunrise. Install dehumidifiers if recurring issue. Monitor leaf wetness duration - keep below 6 hours. Prune lower leaves for airflow.

instruction: How to optimize natural ventilation in 30m x 100m greenhouse?
output: Ventilation area should equal 25-30% of floor area. Ridge vents: continuous opening at 1.5m width. Side vents: 1.2m height along both sides. Wind speed >2 m/s drives natural ventilation. Install wind sensors for automated adjustment. Insect screens reduce ventilation by 30-40% - account in sizing. Temperature difference of 5C creates adequate buoyancy.

instruction: Creating positive pressure to exclude pests and diseases?
output: Install intake fans exceeding exhaust by 15-20%. Maintain 10-15 Pascal positive pressure. Use HEPA filters on intakes for disease exclusion. Insect screening with 50 mesh minimum. Monitor with manometer. Seal all cracks - use smoke test to identify leaks. Energy cost increases 20% but reduces pesticide use 40%.

instruction: Winter heating costs excessive. Energy-saving strategies?
output: Implement thermal screens saving 30-40% energy - deploy at sunset. Maintain different temperature zones. Use temperature integration allowing 4C variation over 24 hours. Insulate north wall with bubble wrap. Perimeter heating more efficient than overhead. Lower night temperature to 15C where possible. Check boiler efficiency - should exceed 85%.

instruction: Optimizing CO2 from combustion heaters safely?
output: Ensure complete combustion - blue flame, no soot. Install CO monitors alarming at 25ppm. Ethylene must stay below 10ppb (causes flower drop). Service burners monthly. Calculate: 1m³ natural gas produces 1.8kg CO2. Ventilate if CO2 exceeds 1500ppm. Never use unvented heaters. Sulfur content must be <0.02%.

instruction: Edge effect causing 5C temperature difference. Mitigation strategies?
output: Install perimeter heating pipes 50cm from walls. Use double-wall polycarbonate on ends for insulation. Position sensitive crops away from edges. Install vertical air circulation fans every 10m along walls. Thermal screens crucial for edges. Monitor with multiple sensors. Consider sacrificial border rows in extreme climates.

instruction: Setting alarm thresholds for critical climate parameters?
output: Temperature: Warning at 10C and 30C, Critical at 5C and 35C. Humidity: Warning <50% and >80%, Critical <30% and >90%. CO2: Warning <200ppm (day), Critical <100ppm. Power failure: Immediate alarm. Set 15-minute delay to prevent false alarms. Test weekly. Multiple notification methods essential.

instruction: Transitioning from heating to cooling mode in spring?
output: Gradual transition over 2-3 weeks. Reduce heating setpoint by 1C every 3 days. Increase ventilation temperature setpoint similarly. Clean cooling pads, test fans before need. Adjust shade screens deployment temperature. Monitor closely during unstable weather. Maintain 4C minimum day/night difference throughout transition.

instruction: Managing microclimate variations in 5000m² greenhouse?
output: Install minimum 5 climate zones with independent controls. Use 20+ temperature sensors in grid pattern. Horizontal airflow fans every 15m for uniformity (0.5m/s air speed). Identify and map microclimates - typically 3-4C variation. Position cultivars according to their preferences. Regular thermal imaging to detect problems.

instruction: Fogging system causing disease issues. Optimization needed.
output: Reduce droplet size to 5-10 microns for complete evaporation. Increase pressure to 70+ bar. Use reverse osmosis water to prevent mineral deposits. Time fogging when VPD >1.5 kPa only. Maximum 30-second bursts with 5-minute intervals. Never fog 2 hours before sunset. Clean nozzles weekly with acid solution.

instruction: How to maintain root zone temperature in winter without bottom heat?
output: Insulate containers with styrofoam or bubble wrap. Use black mulch to absorb solar heat. Water with warm water (20-22C) in morning only. Raise containers off ground on benches. Group plants together for mutual insulation. Consider phase-change materials for heat storage. Minimum root temperature 16C for nutrient uptake.

instruction: Implementing precision climate control with AI integration?
output: Deploy machine learning algorithms using 3 years historical data. Input variables: weather forecast, plant growth stage, energy prices. Predictive control reduces energy 15-20%. Neural networks optimize multiple variables simultaneously. Cloud-based processing with local backup. ROI typically 2-3 years. Requires quality sensor network and data logging.

instruction: Emergency response for 45C heat wave lasting 5 days?
output: Survival mode protocol: Apply 70% shade immediately, run evaporative cooling 24/7, emergency overhead misting every 15 minutes during peak heat. Harvest all ripe/turning fruits. Reduce fertilizer EC by 30%. Night irrigation only. Accept 30-50% flower drop. Focus on plant survival over production. Recovery takes 2-3 weeks post-heat.

instruction: EMERGENCY: Temperature 42°C, humidity 95%, all plants wilting. Immediate action needed.
output: CRITICAL HEAT EMERGENCY PROTOCOL: 1) Open ALL vents immediately - 100% ventilation. 2) Activate all cooling systems - fans, pad cooling, foggers. 3) Emergency shade deployment - use any available shade cloth or emergency whitewash spray. 4) Mist plants every 10 minutes for evaporative cooling. 5) If available, use portable AC units. 6) Harvest all ripe fruit immediately. Monitor every 15 minutes. This combination can kill plants in 2 hours.

instruction: Night temperature dropping to 2°C, heating system failed. How to save plants?
output: FROST EMERGENCY: Cover all plants with row covers, plastic, or blankets immediately. Place containers of hot water throughout greenhouse for thermal mass. Group plants together for mutual protection. Use emergency propane heaters if available (ensure ventilation for CO). Wrap stems with insulation. Mist plants before sunrise to release latent heat. Expect damage below 4°C. Focus on protecting growing points and young fruits.

instruction: CO2 sensor shows 2500ppm, plants showing toxicity symptoms. Ventilation broken.
output: CO2 TOXICITY EMERGENCY: Manually open all vents and doors immediately. Stop CO2 injection. Create cross-ventilation with fans. If no power, create chimney effect by opening bottom and top vents. Symptoms include leaf curl, chlorosis. Levels above 3000ppm toxic. Target 400-1200ppm. Check for combustion heater malfunction producing CO. Monitor workers for headaches, dizziness.

instruction: Power outage expected 48 hours, winter conditions -10°C outside. Preparation?
output: EXTENDED POWER OUTAGE PREP: 1) Pre-heat greenhouse to maximum safe temperature. 2) Install bubble wrap insulation on walls/roof. 3) Prepare propane/kerosene heaters with CO monitors. 4) Group plants, smallest in center. 5) Fill black barrels with hot water for thermal mass. 6) Cover plants with row covers at night. 7) Seal all air leaks. 8) Hand-water only when critical. Prioritize high-value plants. Expect 30-50% losses.

instruction: Humidity stuck at 30%, leaves crispy, VPD reading 2.8 kPa. Correction needed.
output: CRITICAL LOW HUMIDITY: VPD too high causing excessive transpiration stress. Immediately mist walkways (not plants directly). Install wet burlap or evaporative pads. Reduce temperature 2-3°C if possible. Group plants closer. Apply anti-transpirant spray. Reduce air circulation temporarily. Target VPD 0.8-1.2 kPa by achieving 60-70% humidity. Check irrigation - plants need more water in low humidity.

instruction: Greenhouse plastic torn in storm, rain entering, 20% roof damage. Emergency repair?
output: STORM DAMAGE PROTOCOL: 1) Immediate temporary cover with emergency plastic sheeting and repair tape. 2) Secure with rope/wire grid pattern. 3) Install support boards to prevent further tearing. 4) Drain standing water immediately. 5) Increase ventilation to prevent disease. 6) Apply preventive fungicide within 6 hours. 7) Document for insurance. 8) Schedule permanent repair within 48 hours. Monitor for disease outbreak next 7 days.

instruction: DLI only 8 mol/m²/day in winter, plants stretching badly. Supplemental lighting options?
output: INSUFFICIENT LIGHT CORRECTION: Minimum DLI needed is 15-20 mol/m²/day. Install LED supplemental lighting providing 150-200 μmol/m²/s for 12-14 hours. HPS alternative: 400W per 15m². Position 1.5-2m above canopy. Red:blue ratio 3:1 optimal. Run lights 4am-8pm to utilize cheaper electricity. ROI calculation: 20-30% yield increase. Consider reflective ground cover. Prune carefully to maximize light penetration.

instruction: Temperature sensor reads 25°C but plants showing heat stress symptoms. Calibration issue?
output: SENSOR PLACEMENT ERROR: Sensor likely in shaded/ventilated area not representing plant temperature. Leaf temperature can be 5-10°C higher than air. Relocate sensor to plant canopy level in sun. Use infrared thermometer to verify actual leaf temperature. Install multiple sensors for accurate average. Shield sensors from direct radiation but maintain airflow. Recalibrate against known standard. Trust plant symptoms over single sensor.

instruction: Condensation dripping on plants every morning causing disease. Prevention methods?
output: CONDENSATION CONTROL: Implement pre-dawn heating + ventilation protocol starting 1 hour before sunrise. Raise temperature 2°C while ventilating 10% to expel moisture. Install anti-drip plastic or condensation gutters. Maintain minimum pipe temperature 2°C above dew point. Use horizontal airflow fans continuously. Never let humidity exceed 85% at night. Consider installing dehumidifier. This prevents 80% of condensation issues.

instruction: VPD optimization for seedling, vegetative, and fruiting stages? Current readings variable.
output: STAGE-SPECIFIC VPD TARGETS: Seedlings: 0.4-0.8 kPa (high humidity needed). Vegetative: 0.8-1.0 kPa (balanced growth). Fruiting: 1.0-1.3 kPa (generative steering). Night: 0.3-0.5 kPa all stages. Adjust by changing temperature ±2°C or humidity ±10%. Monitor hourly, average over 24h. Use deficit irrigation to increase VPD. Install real-time VPD controller for precision. Improves yield 10-15%.

instruction: Light intensity 1200 PPFD at noon, plants bleaching. Too much light?
output: EXCESSIVE LIGHT STRESS: Tomatoes optimal at 600-800 PPFD, maximum 1000. Deploy 30% shade cloth immediately during 10am-4pm. Symptoms include bleaching, upward leaf curl, photooxidation. Increase humidity to reduce stress. Ensure adequate potassium for stomatal function. Consider diffusion film to scatter light. Gradually acclimate plants if increasing light. High light requires higher CO2 (1200ppm) to utilize.

instruction: Horizontal temperature gradient 10°C across greenhouse. How to achieve uniformity?
output: TEMPERATURE UNIFORMITY: Install HAF (Horizontal Air Flow) fans every 15m in circular pattern - critical for uniformity. Add perimeter heating pipes if edge cooling issue. Check all heaters functioning properly. Install thermal screen at night. Insulate north wall with bubble plastic. Use infrared camera to identify cold spots. Verify door seals. Target <3°C variation. Proper airflow reduces disease 30%.

instruction: CO2 enrichment to 1000ppm showing no benefit. What's limiting factor?
output: CO2 UTILIZATION LIMITS: Check limiting factors hierarchy: 1) Light - need minimum 400 PPFD for CO2 benefit. 2) Temperature - optimal 25-28°C for high CO2. 3) Nutrients - increase feeding 20% with CO2 enrichment. 4) Water - higher transpiration needs consistent moisture. 5) Air circulation - CO2 stratifies without mixing. Verify actual CO2 at canopy level. Only enrichment during light hours. Maximum benefit at 1500ppm with high light.

instruction: Implementing DIF (day-night temperature difference) for height control. Settings?
output: DIF HEIGHT CONTROL: Negative DIF (-3 to -5°C) restricts stem elongation. Example: 18°C day, 22°C night = -4 DIF = compact plants. Positive DIF (+5 to +8°C) promotes stretching if needed. Most effective first 2-3 hours of light. Morning temperature drop particularly effective. Combine with high EC and deficit irrigation for maximum control. Save 20% on growth regulators. Monitor internode length weekly.

instruction: Sudden weather change from cloudy to full sun. Plants wilting despite wet soil.
output: RADIATION STRESS: Sudden light increase causes transpiration to exceed root water uptake. Deploy temporary shade (30%) immediately. Mist plants lightly every 30 minutes. Increase humidity to 70%. Ensure calcium availability for cell membrane stability. Will adapt in 2-3 days. Common after extended cloudy periods. Gradual light increases prevent this. Anti-transpirant spray helps. Monitor leaf temperature.

instruction: Setting up climate zones for propagation vs production areas. Parameters?
output: MULTI-ZONE CLIMATE: Propagation: 24-26°C, 80-85% RH, 100-200 PPFD, minimal air movement. Vegetative: 22-24°C, 70-75% RH, 400 PPFD, moderate airflow. Production: 20-22°C day/16-18°C night, 65-70% RH, 600+ PPFD, good airflow. Use plastic curtains between zones. Independent controls essential. Transition plants gradually over 3-4 days. Energy efficiency improves 25% with zoning.

instruction: Winter heating costs excessive. Energy saving without compromising yield?
output: ENERGY OPTIMIZATION: 1) Install energy screens - save 35-40% heating. 2) Temperature integration - allow ±3°C variation over 24h. 3) Lower night temperature to 15-16°C minimum. 4) Seal all air leaks. 5) Insulate north wall. 6) Use temperature setback when no harvest. 7) Maintain boilers at 85%+ efficiency. 8) Consider root zone heating. Can reduce costs 40-50% maintaining yield.

instruction: Humidity 95% for 3 days, disease outbreak starting. Emergency dehumidification?
output: EMERGENCY DEHUMIDIFICATION: Run heating + minimum ventilation simultaneously - expensive but necessary. Increase temperature 3°C with 15% vent opening. Use all fans maximum speed. If available, run dehumidifiers. Apply preventive fungicide immediately. Remove lower leaves for airflow. Reduce irrigation 30%. Crisis mode - accept energy cost. Target <80% humidity within 6 hours. Disease spreads exponentially above 90%.

instruction: Screen deployment strategy for diffuse light vs energy saving. When to use which?
output: SMART SCREEN MANAGEMENT: Energy screen: Deploy at sunset +30min, retract sunrise -30min. Add second closure 10pm-4am in extreme cold. Gap 5% for moisture escape. Shade screen: Deploy when radiation >700 W/m² outside. Diffusion screen: Use continuously during high light season. Combined system: Shade/diffusion day, energy night. Automated based on sensors. Improves climate stability 40%.

instruction: Measuring and optimizing photosynthesis rate. Target values and methods?
output: PHOTOSYNTHESIS OPTIMIZATION: Target 20-25 μmol CO2/m²/s net photosynthesis. Measure with infrared gas analyzer or calculate from growth rate. Optimal conditions: 800 PPFD light, 1000ppm CO2, 25°C leaf temperature, VPD 1.0 kPa. Light saturation ~1000 PPFD without CO2, ~1500 with CO2. Monitor chlorophyll fluorescence for stress. Increase gradually - photosystem damage irreversible. 10% photosynthesis increase = 8% yield increase.

instruction: Natural ventilation insufficient at 32°C outside. Mechanical cooling options?
output: MECHANICAL COOLING OPTIONS: 1) Pad-and-fan evaporative cooling: 8-12°C reduction, works best in dry climates. 2) High-pressure fog: 5-8°C reduction, increases humidity. 3) Mechanical refrigeration: expensive but precise. 4) Underground pipe cooling: 3-5°C reduction. Combine with maximum ventilation rates (60 air changes/hour). White shade compound on roof. Consider night cooling storage. Cost-benefit best with pad-and-fan.

instruction: Optimizing morning climate transition from night to day settings. Protocol?
output: SUNRISE TRANSITION PROTOCOL: Begin 1 hour before sunrise: 1) Gradually raise temperature 1°C every 20 minutes. 2) Start minimum ventilation to remove moisture. 3) Activate HAF fans. 4) At sunrise, increase temperature setpoint to day level over 1 hour. 5) Open thermal screen gradually (20% every 15 min). 6) Start CO2 injection at 200 PPFD. This prevents condensation, thermal shock, and optimizes early photosynthesis.

instruction: Leaf temperature 35°C but air only 28°C. Cooling strategies?
output: LEAF TEMPERATURE MANAGEMENT: High radiation load causing overheating. Increase transpiration: ensure adequate water, increase air movement around leaves, raise humidity to 60-70%. Apply reflective kaolin clay spray. Install shade screen. Mist environment (not leaves directly) every 20 minutes. Check VPD - may be too high. Ensure adequate potassium for stomatal function. Leaf temperature >30°C reduces photosynthesis 50%.

instruction: Setting up weather station for greenhouse automation. Essential sensors?
output: WEATHER STATION SETUP: Outside: temperature, humidity, wind speed/direction, solar radiation, rain sensor. Inside: temperature (multiple points), humidity, CO2, PAR light sensor. Optional: leaf wetness, soil moisture, EC/pH monitors. Position 2m above ground, away from structures. Data logging 5-minute intervals. Connect to climate computer for predictive control. Calibrate annually. Enables 20-30% better climate control.

instruction: Air circulation pattern design for 30m x 100m greenhouse. Fan placement?
output: OPTIMAL AIR CIRCULATION: Install HAF fans every 15m in two rows, alternating direction to create circular pattern. Fan capacity: 0.1 m³/s per 100m². Mount at gutter height angled 15° downward. Run continuously at variable speed. Add vertical fans at ends for complete mixing. This ensures <2°C temperature difference, uniform CO2, reduced disease. Energy use: 5-10W/m². Essential for uniform growth.

instruction: Integrating root zone heating with air temperature management. Best practice?
output: ROOT ZONE HEATING INTEGRATION: Maintain roots at 18-20°C while reducing air temperature 2-3°C for energy savings. Use hot water pipes under benches or in-floor heating. Start root heating 2 hours before sunrise. Improves nutrient uptake 30% in cool conditions. Air can be 16°C if roots warm. Monitor root temperature separately. Saves 25% heating costs. Critical for winter production.

instruction: CO2 burner causing ethylene buildup. Detection and mitigation?
output: COMBUSTION QUALITY CONTROL: Blue flame good, yellow indicates incomplete combustion producing ethylene/CO. Install CO detector alarming at 25ppm. Ethylene causes flower drop at 10ppb. Service burners monthly, check air intake. Ventilate 5 minutes every 2 hours. Alternative: liquid CO2 eliminates combustion issues. If ethylene detected, ventilate immediately, check all combustion equipment. Consider ethylene scrubbers.

instruction: Implementing predictive climate control using weather forecasts. Setup?
output: PREDICTIVE CONTROL SETUP: Integrate 48-hour weather forecast API with climate computer. Pre-cool before heat waves, pre-heat before cold fronts. Adjust irrigation based on predicted radiation. Modify CO2 strategy for cloudy periods. Example: if storm approaching, reduce humidity 12 hours early to prevent disease. Requires learning algorithm calibration. Saves 15-20% energy, improves crop uniformity 25%.

instruction: Light pollution regulations require blackout at night. Impact on supplemental lighting?
output: BLACKOUT COMPLIANCE: Install automated blackout screens deploying sunset to sunrise when lights on. Use 99% opacity material. Ensure complete edge sealing. Alternative: shift lighting to early morning (3am-sunrise) when regulations may permit. Consider LED with precise control. Document compliance for authorities. May reduce potential lighting hours 30% - adjust intensity accordingly. Legal compliance essential to avoid fines.

instruction: Creating positive pressure greenhouse for pest exclusion. Requirements?
output: POSITIVE PRESSURE SYSTEM: Install intake fans exceeding exhaust by 15-20%. Maintain 10-15 Pascal positive pressure. Filter incoming air with insect screening (50 mesh minimum). Seal all unintended openings. Double-door entry system. Monitor with manometer. Reduces pest entry 70-80%. Increases energy use 20% but reduces pesticide needs 50%. Critical for high-value crops.

instruction: Optimizing shade screen for both cooling and photoperiod control. Programming?
output: DUAL-PURPOSE SHADE PROGRAM: Cooling mode: Deploy when outside radiation >600 W/m² or inside temperature >28°C. Photoperiod mode: Deploy to create short days if needed (variety dependent). Use two screens if possible - light shade for cooling, blackout for photoperiod. Gap ventilation essential. Override for worker safety. Consider photosynthetic efficiency - some shade improves efficiency in high light.

instruction: Emergency cooling using water on greenhouse roof. Risks and protocol?
output: ROOF WATERING EMERGENCY: Only for extreme heat emergencies >40°C. Risks: mineral deposits reducing light, structural stress, increased humidity. Protocol: Use clean water only, apply as fine mist not stream, run 2 minutes every 15 minutes during peak heat. Clean roof within 48 hours. Can reduce temperature 5-8°C. Alternative: external shade cloth safer. Document for insurance - may void warranty.

instruction: Calculating ventilation requirements for CO2 depletion prevention. Formula?
output: VENTILATION CALCULATIONS: Minimum rate = (Photosynthesis rate × Area) / (Outside CO2 - Minimum CO2). Example: 30 μmol/m²/s photosynthesis, 1000m², outside 400ppm, minimum 250ppm = needs 3 air changes/hour. Double for safety margin. Natural ventilation needs 25% vent area. Mechanical: 0.05 m³/s per m². Monitor actual CO2 to verify. Critical for non-enriched greenhouses.

instruction: Thermal screen management during rain. Humidity vs energy dilemma?
output: RAIN PERIOD MANAGEMENT: Keep screen 95% closed for energy saving, 5% gap for moisture escape. Increase minimum pipe temperature 2°C to prevent condensation on screen. Run HAF fans continuously. Monitor humidity - if >85%, increase gap to 10%. After rain stops, wait 1 hour before fully closing. Accept slight energy loss to prevent disease. Critical balance - disease costs more than heating.

instruction: Comparing LED spectrums for tomato production. Optimal configuration?
output: LED SPECTRUM OPTIMIZATION: Optimal: 85% red (660nm), 15% blue (450nm) for production. Add far-red (730nm) 5% for stem elongation if needed. UV-A (385nm) 1-2% improves flavor/color. Green not essential but 5% helps visual inspection. Adjustable spectrum ideal - more blue in vegetative stage. Efficiency: 2.7-3.0 μmol/J. Position 1-1.5m above canopy. Better spectrum worth 10% premium.

instruction: Wind damage prevention in high wind area. Structural reinforcement?
output: WIND PROTECTION STRATEGIES: Install windbreak (50% porosity) at 3× greenhouse height distance. Reinforce structure: additional ground posts, cable bracing, stronger connectors. Use reinforced plastic or polycarbonate. Automate vent closure at wind >40 km/h. Emergency protocol: partial vent opening to equalize pressure. Regular inspection of cladding attachment. Insurance documentation critical. Can withstand 120 km/h with proper reinforcement.

instruction: Sulfur evaporator for disease control affecting climate sensors. Solutions?

instruction: Optimizing greenhouse orientation for year-round production at 45°N latitude.

instruction: Heat stress index shows danger level. Worker safety protocols?

instruction: Dew point control to prevent condensation on fruits. Target values?

instruction: Integrating renewable energy (solar/wind) for climate control. Feasibility?

instruction: Setting climate alarms and emergency response protocols. Priority parameters?

instruction: Calculating heat loss and heating requirements for greenhouse. Method?

instruction: Photoperiod manipulation for controlling flowering. Light/dark requirements?

instruction: Comparing foggers vs misters vs pad-and-fan for cooling. Which for what?

instruction: Snow load approaching structural limit (30kg/m²). Emergency measures?

instruction: Optimizing natural ventilation using buoyancy and wind effects. Design principles?

instruction: Climate battery system using underground thermal mass. Implementation?

instruction: Managing ethylene from ripening fruit affecting new flowers. Control methods?
output: ETHYLENE MANAGEMENT: Maintain excellent ventilation - minimum 4 air changes/hour during harvest season. Harvest fruits at breaker stage to reduce ethylene production. Remove overripe/damaged fruits immediately. Consider ethylene scrubbers using potassium permanganate. Keep temperatures <25°C to slow ethylene production. instruction: Comparing control strategies: thermostatic vs VPD vs enthalpy. Which when?

instruction: Setting up redundant climate control systems. Critical components?

instruction: Optimizing twilight period management (sunrise/sunset). Transition protocols?

instruction: Dealing with temperature inversion in greenhouse. Air circulation solutions?

instruction: Calibrating and validating climate models for specific greenhouse. Process?

instruction: Optimizing CO2 distribution in large greenhouse. Delivery methods?

instruction: Calculating and managing vapor pressure deficit in real-time. Tools needed?

Foliar calcium chloride 0.5% provides temporary relief. Improve air circulation for transpiration.

instruction: Transitioning from vegetative to generative growth nutritionally?
output: Gradual 2-week transition: Reduce nitrogen from 200 to 150ppm, increase potassium from 200 to 300ppm. Raise EC from 2.0 to 2.8. Switch from 3-1-2 to 1-1-2 NPK ratio. Lower ammonium to <10% of total N. Mild water stress (allow slight wilting) triggers flowering. Monitor plant balance - aim for 15cm between flower clusters.

instruction: Tissue test shows: N 2.8%, P 0.2%, K 2.1%, Ca 3.5%, Mg 0.8%. Interpretation?
output: Nitrogen low (need 3.5-4.5%), Phosphorus deficient (need 0.3-0.5%), Potassium very low (need 3.5-5%), Calcium excessive (1.5-2.5% optimal), Magnesium high (0.3-0.5% optimal). Excess Ca and Mg blocking K uptake. Reduce calcium inputs, increase K to 350ppm, add phosphorus. Check pH - high pH reduces P availability.

instruction: Optimizing fertigation frequency in rockwool vs coir vs soil?
output: Rockwool: 8-15 irrigations daily, 3-5 minute duration, 30% drainage. Coir: 4-8 irrigations daily, 5-8 minutes, 20% drainage. Soil: 1-2 irrigations daily, until 10% drainage. Start 2 hours after sunrise, finish 2 hours before sunset. Increase frequency, not volume, in hot weather. Night irrigation only in extreme heat.

instruction: Boron deficiency symptoms appearing. Safe application method?
output: Critical - boron has narrow safety margin. Deficiency: brittle stems, poor fruit set, corky areas. Apply borax at 0.25g per plant in solution or 0.1% foliar spray. Never exceed 0.5ppm in solution - toxicity occurs at 1ppm. Weekly applications better than single large dose. Check pH - availability decreases above pH 7.0.

instruction: Creating custom hydroponic solution for hard water (300ppm CaCO₃)?
output: Account for existing minerals: You have ~120ppm Ca, 24ppm Mg from water. Reduce calcium nitrate by 50%, eliminate magnesium sulfate initially. Use nitric acid for pH adjustment and nitrogen source. May need ammonium nitrate for remaining N. Monitor micronutrients - high pH water often has reduced availability. Consider RO system if bicarbonates >150ppm.

instruction: Silicon supplementation showing no effect. Application issue?
output: Silicon requires specific conditions: pH 5.5-6.0 for uptake, potassium silicate form most available. Apply at 100ppm Si, separately from other nutrients (precipitates with calcium). Benefits visible after 3-4 weeks: stronger stems, disease resistance, heat tolerance. Foliar application ineffective. Most beneficial in soilless systems lacking natural Si.

instruction: Managing nutrition during 35C heat stress?
output: Heat stress nutrition protocol: Reduce EC by 20% (prevents additional osmotic stress), increase calcium to 200ppm (cell membrane stability), add potassium for stomatal function. Foliar spray with amino acids and seaweed extract for stress relief. Avoid ammonium nitrogen. Increase irrigation frequency 50%. Apply nutrients during cooler morning hours only.

instruction: Leaf analysis optimal but yield poor. Hidden hunger concept?
output: Hidden hunger - adequate tissue levels but functional deficiency. Causes: 1) Nutrient imbalance despite adequate individual levels, 2) Poor root health limiting uptake during peak demand, 3) Environmental stress reducing utilization, 4) Variety-specific requirements. Solution: Foliar feeding during critical stages, improve root zone conditions, check variety needs.

instruction: Implementing precision fertilization with ion-selective sensors?
output: Install sensors for NO₃, K, Ca in drainage. Real-time adjustment algorithm: If K drops >20% input to drainage, increase K injection. 15-minute measurement intervals. Maintain input/drainage ratios: N 85%, P 90%, K 85%. Calibrate sensors weekly. Backup with lab analysis monthly. Typical precision improvement: fertilizer savings 20-30%, yield increase 5-10%.

instruction: Chloride toxicity from irrigation water (80ppm Cl). Management?
output: Tomatoes sensitive to chloride >70ppm. Increase leaching fraction to 30%, maintain drainage to prevent accumulation. Avoid KCl fertilizers, use sulfate forms. Increase calcium to compete with chloride uptake. Consider blending with rainwater or RO water. Foliar symptoms: marginal leaf burn progressing inward. Grafting onto tolerant rootstock helps.

instruction: How to fertigate during fruit ripening for maximum flavor?
output: Flavor optimization: Increase EC to 3.5-4.0 (mild stress concentrates sugars), K:N ratio 3:1 for sugar development. Reduce irrigation 20% but maintain consistency. Calcium for cell wall integrity affects texture. Stop nitrogen 2 weeks before harvest. Add sulfur for flavor compounds. Harvest at full color for maximum sugars.

instruction: Manganese toxicity in acid soil (pH 5.2). Correction strategy?
output: Mn toxicity causes brown spots with chlorotic halos, interveinal chlorosis. Immediately lime soil to pH 6.5 using dolomitic lime (adds Mg which antagonizes Mn). Flood soil temporarily to change Mn oxidation state. Add organic matter to chelate excess Mn. Foliar iron competes with Mn uptake. Avoid manganese-containing fungicides.

instruction: Optimizing nutrient film technique (NFT) for tomatoes?
output: NFT requirements: Flow rate 1-2 L/min per channel, channel slope 1-2%. Maintain film depth 3-5mm. EC 2.0-2.5, increase to 3.0 during fruiting. Oxygenate solution to >6ppm DO.
